channel.name: Is there a way to acces the binary that is produced when a ZkProgram is compiled?

messages.content: I want to compile a ZKProgram on the client once and store it on the client. This way when a user refreshes the page or comes back to the web page there is no waiting time for compiling the zk-Program. Currently every time the web page gets reloaded the Worker compiles the ZKProgram again which take some time and feels unnecessary.

Hey, there’s no binary generated when compiling a smart contract. Instead, you general something called a verification key and a prover. The verification key is available in a JON format and can be serialised to verify proofs. However, you can’t yet serialise and deserialise the prover artifacts. That means, the client needs to compile the program before generating a proof

Thanks for your answer! Does this mean that every time a client compiles the ZKProgram it generates a different verification key, or can I put the verification key in a contract on chain so clients can verify the proofs generated by the client side ZKProgram?

Every time the client compiles the program she receives the same verification key as everyone else (assuming the code is the exact same, of course!). You can then take this verification key and deploy it on-chain, that’s how Mina zkApps work :)

How do we ensure that the client does not temper with the code, since the client uploads the  verification keys to verify. My assumption was that only the developer uploads a verification key which then will be used by all the clients. What you are saying means that the verification happens based on clients verification key.

Oh the client does not upload the verification key, it’s deployed on-chain by the one who deploys the smart contract (like you assumed correctly) Users who want to interact with the contract on-chain send their proofs to verify them to the network

I am using the ```Experimental.ZKProgram()``` to generate our proofs on the client (this way the client does not get a prompt to sign a transaction). Now I want to verify the the proofs generated by the ZKProgram. Is this enough for me to verify the on-chain or do I need to write a different "contract"?

For context, `SmartContract` gives you a builtin way to "write a ZkProgram and verify it inchain". It's the main zkApp flow. It sounds like you want to circumvent that somehow, but I don't quite get why.

In any case, Mina has builtin capability of verifying proofs associated with zkApp transactions (those created by `SmartContract`). It doesn't support verifying arbitrary other proofs like yours would be.
Also, all interaction with a Mina node is via transaction, so the idea of "avoiding to create sign a transaction" is fundamentally flawed.
Can't wait for not having to compile any longer.

Yeah, you are right, circom creates a wasm file for witness generation.
what I meant was total proving time is large compared to generating proof with snarkjs.  (excluding the compilation time.). I don't know all the internals of kimchi but I think the recursive part of the proof takes majority of the time
I was mainly experimenting with  small circuits (verifying a valid signature, etc  ~10K constraints).

Yeah, snarkyjs being slower than circom/snarkjs is definitely a point to address. For small proofs the recursion overhead kicks in, for larger proofs it's less of a factor. But in any case there's lots of leverage we have to make proofs faster and you can expect basically everything to become much faster in the next months -- this was something we never really focused on in the past and now are tackling
This is huge.
Glad to see the focus on performance!
Are there any updates? Do you know when it will be available?
No update, but still something that's on the table for us to do very soon
Can we serialize the prover now for a ZkProgram? need to use it in browser to generate proofs @gregor
no, issue is still TODO, I'll post an update once we made progress
btw, you can track all changes we released in our changelog: https://github.com/o1-labs/o1js/blob/main/CHANGELOG.md

I promised an update so here it is! I made a lot of progress on this. There are two PRs that I'll try to land in the next few days.
https://github.com/o1-labs/o1js/pull/1187
https://github.com/o1-labs/o1js/pull/1197
On the second one, compiling only takes 3s when the prover keys are cached
caching happens by default in nodejs and not on the web (but it's also configurable and you can pass your own cache to `compile()`)
Do you by any chance have some numbers on how big the prover keys will be on disk?
yes, about 50MB per small-ish circuit
ok thats actually very nice
Update: Prover caching is released! https://github.com/o1-labs/o1js/pull/1197
